extracted_ttps.description: The attacker uses phishing emails with malicious attachments to gain initial access
The attacker uses a malicious RAR file containing a Windows Shortcut file to execute the SugarGh0st RAT payload
The attacker uses social engineering to trick users into executing the SugarGh0st RAT malware
The attacker uses command line tools such as cmd and cscript to execute malicious commands
The attacker collects data from the local system, including files and registry keys
The attacker collects system information, including computer name, operating system version, and drive information
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker uses JavaScript to drop and execute the SugarGh0st RAT payload
The attacker modifies registry keys to maintain persistence on the compromised system
The attacker creates a registry subkey to establish persistence
The attacker uses remote services to access and control the victim's machine
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Input Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Suspicious Office Process Spawning Shell with Network Activity
rules.description: Detects Office applications spawning command shells with indicators of malicious attachment execution (e.g., document spawning PowerShell with download commands)
falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros executing administrative scripts
Developer workflows involving document-embedded scripts

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

rules.title: Suspicious Execution via Malicious RAR and Shortcut File
rules.description: Detects execution of SugarGh0st RAT via a malicious RAR file containing a Windows Shortcut file, based on command line indicators and parent process.
falsepositives: Legitimate software installations using RAR files with shortcut files
Administrative scripts utilizing .lnk or .scr files

rules.title: Suspicious Command Line Interpreter Usage with Long Commands
rules.description: Detects cmd.exe or cscript.exe execution with long command lines from non-explorer parents under system accounts
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts
Scheduled tasks executing complex commands

rules.title: Detection: Data from Local System
rules.description: The attacker collects data from the local system, including files and registry keys
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: System Information Discovery via SugarGh0st RAT
rules.description: Detects execution of system discovery commands indicative of SugarGh0st RAT activity, including systeminfo, hostname, and wmic queries, spawned by suspicious parent processes.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts using similar commands via installers or scripting engines

rules.title: Process Injection via Memory Manipulation APIs
rules.description: Detects process injection patterns through memory manipulation APIs in suspicious processes and their parent relationships
falsepositives: Legitimate administration tools using .NET memory APIs
Security products performing process introspection
Web servers spawning maintenance scripts with encoded commands

rules.title: SugarGh0st RAT Registry Modification for Persistence
rules.description: Detects SugarGh0st RAT modifying registry keys using reg.exe under SYSTEM context with specific command-line patterns indicative of persistence.

detection.condition: selection_reg and selection_system and not filter_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts running under SYSTEM account with non-standard parent processes
Third-party software performing registry modifications via reg.exe under SYSTEM context

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation Patterns Suggesting SugarGh0st RAT
rules.description: Detects SugarGh0st RAT activity through command-line patterns and parent process relationships associated with remote service exploitation.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell encoding
Software installers using msiexec/rundll32 legitimately

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation with Encoded Command
rules.description: Detects attempts to create or modify system processes using command-line interpreters with suspicious encoded commands
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded parameters
Application installers using command-line utilities

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

rules.title: Suspicious Process with Application Layer Network Patterns
rules.description: Detects processes using application layer protocols for C2 via command line URL patterns and network utility executables
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using HTTP(S) for downloads
DevOps automation tools fetching resources
Web development workflows

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Obfuscation via Long Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects PowerShell executing long base64-encoded commands indicative of obfuscated payloads
falsepositives: Legitimate PowerShell scripts using encoded commands for administration
Package managers or deployment tools employing encoded parameters

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

rules.title: Network Service Discovery via Command-line Utilities
rules.description: Detects common commands used for network service discovery including PowerShell NetTCP modules, WMIC service queries, net view/group commands, and ARP/NBTSTAT enumeration flags.

detection.condition: selection1 or selection2 or selection3 or selection4 or selection5

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration scripts
Network troubleshooting activities

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate backup operations
Software installation processes
Compressed file extraction

rules.title: Suspicious Office Process Spawning Shell with Input Capture Patterns
rules.description: Detects WINWORD.EXE spawning PowerShell/CMD with command-line patterns associated with input capture and credential harvesting
falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros using PowerShell for automation
Administrative scripts initiated from Office documents

rules.title: Account Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Account Discovery activity via command line using various system commands
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Scripted maintenance tasks

rules.title: Screen Capture Activity via Capture Utilities
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity through command line patterns and suspicious parent processes, excluding known legitimate tools.

detection.condition: selection and parent_selection and not exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate use of screen capture tools by users
Admin troubleshooting scripts that include screen capture functionality

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

rules.title: Registry Run Key Modification via Uncommon Process
rules.description: Detects modifications to Windows Registry Run/RunOnce keys from unexpected parent processes, indicating potential persistence mechanisms.
falsepositives: Legitimate software installers creating startup entries
System administration tools modifying registry keys

attacks.command: echo 'This is a benign phishing email body.' > %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Create a benign text file mimicking a phishing email body.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_email.txt is created in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Compress the phishing email into a zip archive, simulating a malicious attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named phishing_email.zip is created in the temp directory, containing the phishing email text file.

attacks.description: Decode a potentially malicious attachment, simulating the execution of a phishing payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: A decoded file named decoded_phishing_email.txt is created in the temp directory, simulating the execution of a phishing payload.

attacks.command: echo 'Malicious attachment' > phishing_email.txt; cat phishing_email.txt | mail -s 'Phishing Email' user@example.com
attacks.description: Basic phishing email simulation using echo and mail commands
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a phishing email with a malicious attachment to the specified user

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation using bash and a malicious payload script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a malicious payload script, makes it executable, and runs it

attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using sudo and a malicious root payload script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a malicious root payload script, makes it executable, and runs it with elevated privileges

attacks.description: Downloads a benign RAR file and extracts its contents to the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The RAR file is downloaded and extracted to the temp directory

attacks.description: Executes a benign Windows Shortcut file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The Windows Shortcut file is executed

attacks.description: Executes a benign Windows Shortcut file using the command prompt
attacks.expected_behavior: The Windows Shortcut file is executed

attacks.description: Basic: Creates a malicious script, makes it executable, and runs it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed, and its payload will be run

attacks.description: Intermediate: Downloads a malicious script and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be downloaded and executed, and its payload will be run

attacks.command: bash -c "echo 'malicious payload' > /tmp/malicious.sh; chmod +x /tmp/malicious.sh; at -f /tmp/malicious.sh now + 1 minute"
attacks.description: Advanced: Schedules a malicious script to run at a later time using the at command
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be scheduled to run at a later time, and its payload will be executed

attacks.description: Basic command execution using cmd.exe to create a test file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's temp directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution using powershell.exe to display a message box.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the text 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c net user testuser /add && net localgroup administrators testuser /add
attacks.description: Advanced command execution to create a new user and add them to the administrators group.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new user named 'testuser' and adds this user to the local administrators group.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution using bash to create and read a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World' and then prints the content of the file

attacks.description: Advanced command execution using bash to create a directory, create a file, and read the file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named testdir in the /tmp directory, creates a file named test.txt in the testdir directory with the content 'Hello World', and then prints the content of the file

attacks.description: Get the current username
attacks.expected_behavior: Print the current username to the console

attacks.description: Get network configuration information
attacks.expected_behavior: Print network configuration information to the console

attacks.description: Get the Windows product name from the registry
attacks.expected_behavior: Print the Windows product name to the console

attacks.description: Lists all files in the /etc/ directory in a detailed format, demonstrating basic data collection from the local system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of files and directories within /etc/, including their permissions, ownership, and timestamps.

attacks.description: Finds all .txt files in the /home directory and its subdirectories, printing their paths, demonstrating intermediate data collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the paths of all .txt files found in the /home directory and its subdirectories.

attacks.description: Searches for the string 'keyword' recursively in all files within the /var/log/ directory, demonstrating advanced data collection from log files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display lines from files in /var/log/ that contain the string 'keyword', requiring admin privileges to access log files.

attacks.description: Gathers detailed system information including OS version, hardware, and hotfixes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: Retrieves the operating system caption and version.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the OS caption and version in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to retrieve drive information including device ID, size, and free space.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays drive information in the PowerShell window.

attacks.description: Print system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information including kernel version, hostname, and operating system

attacks.description: Print operating system release information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system release information

attacks.description: Print Linux Standard Base information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays Linux Standard Base information including distributor, release, and codename

attacks.description: Basic process injection using PowerShell to start notepad and inject calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad starts, and calc.exe is injected into it, demonstrating basic process injection.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using rundll32 to inject a beep sound into the user32.dll process
attacks.expected_behavior: A beep sound is produced, indicating successful injection into the user32.dll process.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to start cmd and write to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello', demonstrating advanced process injection and file operations.

attacks.description: Inject a benign payload into a running process using gdb
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload will be injected into the process, and the process will continue running without any issues

attacks.description: Inject a benign payload into a running process using gdb and background the process
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload will be injected into the process, and the process will continue running in the background without any issues

attacks.description: Inject a benign payload into a running process using gdb with admin privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload will be injected into the process, and the process will continue running without any issues, but with elevated privileges

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run cmd.exe at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key will be added to run cmd.exe at startup

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run cmd.exe at startup with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key will be added to run cmd.exe at startup with elevated privileges

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run cmd.exe at startup using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key will be added to run cmd.exe at startup using PowerShell

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the system startup script, requiring root privileges for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will append 'evil_command' to /etc/rc.local, which will be executed on the next system reboot.

attacks.description: Uses sudo to append a malicious script to the bash configuration file that runs for all users, potentially allowing for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will append 'malicious_script' to /etc/bash.bashrc, which could execute malicious code for all users upon their next login.

attacks.description: Modifies the system startup script to replace the exit command with a malicious one, requiring root privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will modify /etc/rc.local to execute 'evil_command' instead of exiting cleanly on startup, potentially causing system instability or executing malicious code.

attacks.description: Start the Remote Procedure Call (RPC) service to enable remote access
attacks.expected_behavior: The RPC service will start, allowing remote access to the system

attacks.description: Configure the RPC service to start automatically on boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The RPC service will be configured to start automatically on boot

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to execute a remote command on a test PC
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute on the remote PC and return a list of processes

attacks.description: Establish a basic SSH connection to a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: A remote shell is established, allowing the attacker to execute commands on the victim's machine

attacks.description: Use SSH port forwarding to access a remote service
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote service is accessible through the forwarded port, allowing the attacker to interact with it

attacks.description: Use SSH to execute a command remotely
attacks.expected_behavior: The command is executed on the remote host, and the output is displayed locally

attacks.description: List all running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes

attacks.description: Create a new service
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service named TestService

attacks.description: Create a new process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a new command prompt process

attacks.description: Open cron table for editing to schedule a new system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new cron job

attacks.description: Start a new system service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to start a system service named 'myservice' using systemd

attacks.description: Modify system startup by adding a new script to the default runlevels
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds the 'myscript' script to the default runlevels, so it runs on system startup

attacks.description: Start the telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol usage for potential C2 communications.
attacks.expected_behavior: The telnet service starts, allowing for potential command and control communications over the application layer protocol.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory, demonstrating encoded command execution and file system interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in the %TEMP% directory containing 'Hello World', showcasing PowerShell's ability to execute commands and interact with the file system.

attacks.description: Utilize certutil to download a file from a URL and then display its contents, simulating a C2 channel over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt is downloaded from the specified URL and its contents are displayed in the command prompt, demonstrating the use of certutil for C2 communications.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 for incoming connections using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will start listening on port 8080, waiting for an incoming connection.

attacks.description: Establish a connection to example.com on port 80 using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attempt to connect to example.com on port 80, which could be used for further communication or data transfer.

attacks.description: Send an HTTP request to example.com using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a basic HTTP GET request to example.com, demonstrating the use of the HTTP protocol for communication.

attacks.description: Encode a test file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an encoded file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Decode a base64 string using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a decoded file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a file, then encode it using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an encoded file in the temp directory

attacks.command: echo 'This is a benign string' > $HOME/obfuscated_file.txt; base64 $HOME/obfuscated_file.txt > $HOME/obfuscated_file.base64
attacks.description: Create a file with a benign string, then encode it using Base64 to obfuscate its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated_file.txt is created with a benign string, and its Base64 encoded version is saved as obfuscated_file.base64 in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Use OpenSSL to encrypt a file using AES-256-CBC, further obfuscating its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file obfuscated_file.txt is encrypted and saved as obfuscated_file.enc in the user's home directory, requiring a password to decrypt.

attacks.description: Compress a file using gzip and change its permissions to make it less accessible, adding another layer of obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file obfuscated_file.txt is compressed into obfuscated_file.gz, and its permissions are changed to allow only the owner to read, write, or execute it.

attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all active connections and listening ports, indicating potential network services

attacks.description: Display IP configuration to reveal information about the network and running services

attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all listening TCP connections, indicating potential network services

attacks.expected_behavior: Lists open TCP ports on the target IP, indicating potential network services.

attacks.description: Intermediate network service discovery using netstat to list all listening network connections and filtering for LISTEN state.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of processes listening on network ports, aiding in service discovery.

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery focusing on UDP port 53, commonly used for DNS services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans UDP port 53 on the target IP, which can indicate the presence of a DNS service.

attacks.description: Archives all files in the Public Documents folder into a zip file named 'archive.zip' in the temp directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.

attacks.description: Changes directory to the Public Documents folder and creates a tar archive of all files in that directory, saving it to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of the files in the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Uses .NET to create a zip archive from the Public Documents folder, demonstrating an alternative method of archiving data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the files in the Public Documents folder using .NET classes.

attacks.description: Create a 7z archive of collected data

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Input Capture'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.StartPosition = 'CenterScreen'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Please enter your credentials:'; $label.AutoSize = $true; $label.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,10); $form.Controls.Add($label); $textBox = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.TextBox; $textBox.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(10,30); $textBox.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(260,20); $form.Controls.Add($textBox); $button = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Button; $button.Text = 'Submit'; $button.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(100,60); $button.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(80,25); $form.Controls.Add($button); $button.Add_Click({ $creds = $textBox.Text; $form.Close(); }); $form.ShowDialog() | Out-Null; "$creds" > "%TEMP%\captured_input.txt""
attacks.description: This command creates a simple form to capture user input, simulating a credential capture scenario. It uses PowerShell to create a GUI form, which is a more advanced approach.
attacks.expected_behavior: A form will appear, prompting the user to enter credentials. Upon submission, the form will close, and the input will be saved to a file in the TEMP directory.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Please enter your password: && set /p password= && echo %password% > "%TEMP%\captured_password.txt""
attacks.description: This command uses the command prompt to capture user input by prompting the user to enter a password. It's a basic approach to demonstrate input capture.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command prompt will ask the user to enter a password, and upon entering, it will save the input to a file in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: This command opens Notepad with a file in the TEMP directory, allowing the user to input data. After a short delay, it captures the content of the file and logs it to another file, simulating the capture of input over time.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will open with a file. After 10 seconds, the content of the file will be logged to another file in the TEMP directory, demonstrating the capture of user input over a short period.

attacks.description: Lists properties of the keyboard device, potentially for identifying input capture opportunities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of properties for the specified keyboard device.

attacks.command: sudo tcpdump -i any tcp port 22 -w capture.pcap
attacks.description: Captures network traffic on port 22 (SSH) and writes it to a file, potentially capturing login credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures and saves network traffic to a file named capture.pcap.

attacks.description: Records the terminal session, including any input, to a file named output.txt.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts recording the terminal session and saves it to output.txt.

attacks.description: Lists local groups on the system, indirectly helping in account discovery by showing group membership.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local groups on the system.

attacks.description: Displays the current user's account information, including group memberships, which aids in account discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows detailed information about the current user's account.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to list local user accounts and their descriptions, demonstrating account discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists local user accounts with their descriptions.

attacks.description: Basic account discovery using 'getent' to display all user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Intermediate account discovery using 'getent' to display all groups and their members
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all groups and their members on the system

attacks.description: Advanced account discovery using 'getent' to display shadow password information (may require admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays shadow password information for all user accounts, which may include password expiration dates and other security settings

attacks.description: Capture the screen using mspaint and save to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a bitmap image in the temporary directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save('%TEMP%\screenshot.png');"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG image in the temporary directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$signature = @'[DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr GetDesktopWindow(); [DllImport("user32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr GetWindowDC(IntPtr hWnd); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr CreateCompatibleDC(IntPtr hdc); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr CreateCompatibleBitmap(IntPtr hdc, int nWidth, int nHeight); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern IntPtr SelectObject(IntPtr hdc, IntPtr hgdiobj); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern bool StretchBlt(IntPtr hdcDest, int nXOrig, int nYOrig, int nWidth, int nHeight, IntPtr hdcSrc, int nXOrigSrc, int nYOrigSrc, int nWidthSrc, int nHeightSrc, int dwRop); [DllImport("gdi32.dll")] public static extern bool DeleteDC(IntPtr hdc);'; Add-Type -MemberDefinition $signature -Name APISetup -Namespace WIA; $desktop = [WIA.APISetup]::GetDesktopWindow(); $dc = [WIA.APISetup]::GetWindowDC($desktop); $memdc = [WIA.APISetup]::CreateCompatibleDC($dc); $bmp = [WIA.APISetup]::CreateCompatibleBitmap($dc, 1920, 1080); $hbm = [WIA.APISetup]::SelectObject($memdc, $bmp); [WIA.APISetup]::StretchBlt($memdc, 0, 0, 1920, 1080, $dc, 0, 0, 1920, 1080, 0x00CC0020); [System.Drawing.Bitmap]::FromHbitmap($bmp).Save('%TEMP%\screenshot.bmp'); [WIA.APISetup]::DeleteDC($memdc); [WIA.APISetup]::DeleteDC($dc);'
attacks.description: Capture the screen using low-level Windows API calls from PowerShell and save to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a bitmap image in the temporary directory. This command is more complex and uses low-level API calls, making it potentially more risky.

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot and save it to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be captured and saved to /tmp/screenshot.png

attacks.description: Capture the screen as a video and save it to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen will be captured as a video and saved to /tmp/screen_capture.mp4

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot of a selected region and save it to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the selected region will be captured and saved to /tmp/screenshot.png

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v TestRun /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key to run a command upon user login, writing 'Test' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry key that executes a command to write 'Test' to %TEMP%\test.txt upon user login.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "New-Item -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; New-ItemProperty -Path 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' -Name TestPSRun -Value 'powershell -Command "echo TestPS > %TEMP%\testps.txt"' -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a new registry key and add a property that runs a PowerShell command upon user login, writing 'TestPS' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry key and property that executes a PowerShell command to write 'TestPS' to %TEMP%\testps.txt upon user login.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v TestRunAdmin /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo TestAdmin > %TEMP%\testadmin.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key to run a command upon system startup, writing 'TestAdmin' to a file in the temp directory. This requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a registry key that executes a command to write 'TestAdmin' to %TEMP%\testadmin.txt upon system startup.

attacks.description: Basic: Adds a crontab entry to execute a script at reboot using a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new crontab entry is added to execute the specified script at system reboot.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Appends a reboot cron job to touch a file without using a temporary file, directly modifying the crontab.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file is touched at /tmp/persistence_test upon system reboot, indicating the cron job executed successfully.

attacks.command: sudo systemctl enable --now test.service; echo '[Service]\nExecStart=/path/to/malicious/script.sh' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/test.service
attacks.description: Advanced: Creates and enables a systemd service to execute a script, demonstrating persistence via systemd.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified script is executed as a systemd service, showing persistence capabilities.
